I received an email from Steph that told me the solution. You do not
need test.jar in your classpath. The problem I had was where JUnit was
installed. If the directory path to the JUnit directory has a space in
it ("C:\Documents and Settings" in his case; "C:\Program Files" in my
case), the class locator has a problem with the space. He suggested it
might be because it converts it to the hex %20 representation. This
does not seem to cause a problem for the JAR files located through the
classpath, only those loaded explicitly. I moved my install directory
for JUnit to C:\JavaDev\JUnit, changed my classpath for the junit.jar,
and it ran fine.

This should probably be in the FAQ as it seems a lot of people hit it
under Windows, especially as Sun's default install for their Java
directory is under Program Files.

I have not moved it to my Sun box to test it there yet.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "rikard_land" <riceland@s...> wrote:
> I get the same error during installation test 
> ("ClassNotFoundException" in test "testJarClassLoading"). The 
> file "test.jar" (with path) is included in classpath, as well as 
> current directory. I use Java SDK 1.4.2.03.
> 
> JUnit seems to run fine apart from this, but I suppose I will have 
> problems as soon as I start fiddling with jar files... 
> 
> Did you ever solve it?  
> 
> Regards,
> Rikard
